A month after the election, unsupported claims of ballot fraud are still spreading online. A video on Facebook purports to have captured the crime in action.

The video shows a man working on a computer at "Gwinnett County Election Central." He then relocates to a laptop, where he appears to click through various files before removing a USB stick from the laptop. The computer screens are too blurry to identify the man's actions. He then grabs what appears to be a notebook and leaves the room.
At least two people narrate the video and raise concerns about the man's actions.

"Watch a Dominion Representative ... responsible for tabulating ballots and certifying results, download data to a USB from the Election Management Server, plug it into a laptop, manipulate the data, then palm the USB," the person who posted the video wrote in its caption. She did not respond to USA TODAY's request for comment.

The video appears to have first been published on the YouTube channel "Neon Revolt" on Nov. 30. The information in the caption is attributed "Codemonkey," a former administrator for 8kun, the conspiracy-peddling site previously known as 8chan. In a tweet, he says the video was recorded by Twitter user @launa_usa, though the date on which it was recorded is unknown.
More:Fact check: Claims linking Dominion Voting Systems to Democrats are wrong or misleading
There's no evidence the individual in the video was doing anything but his job.

Gabriel Sterling, Georgia's voting system implementation manager, addressed the claim in a public statement Tuesday, saying a young elections employee in Gwinnett County received death threats online.

“A 20-something tech in Gwinnett County today has death threats and a noose put out saying he should be hung for treason because he was transferring a report on batches from an EMS (Election Management Server) to a county computer so he could read it," Sterling said. He also directly called out President Donald Trump and Georgia's U.S. senators for not condemning violent threats toward election workers.
USA TODAY did identify threatening tweets on the tech employee's Twitter account. He did not respond to USA TODAY's request for comment.
More:'It has to stop': Georgia election official slams Trump's rhetoric on voting fraud
Joe Sorenson, a spokesperson for Gwinnett County, confirmed that explanation to USA TODAY, too.

"This is a Dominion technician producing a data report on the server and saving the report to a Dominion USB thumb drive and then using a laptop to filter requested information," he said. "The Dominion servers are not equipped with Excel and counties are not authorized to install any hardware or software on these systems."
More:Fact check: Wisconsin county did not have a glitch that stole votes from Trump

When asked by Fox News whether a poll worker could use a USB thumb drive to alter candidates' votes, Michael Steel, a spokesperson for Dominion Voting Systems, said that vote tabulators do not have such access and that the machines aren't connected to the internet.
"It’s not physically possible to do what they’re describing," he said.

A national coalition of election security officials, which includes the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency and the National Association of State Election Directors, described the 2020 election as "the most secure in American history."

The claim that a video shows a Dominion Voting Systems tech worker in Gwinnett County, Georgia, manipulating votes is FALSE. State and local election officials and a spokesperson for Dominion explain such manipulation is not possible. Our research uncovered no evidence to support the claim.
